abstract.p: New York Rangers minor league report discusses players who are playing in respective league playoffs (S)

block.p: The Rangers' season ended on April 9, without a playoff appearance for the third consecutive year. But the Rangers' top minor-league affiliate, Hartford, is still going strong.

On Sunday, Hartford wrapped up its A.H.L. quarterfinal series, 4 games to 1, with a 2-0 shutout of Worcester. And now, the Wolf Pack can expect Pavel Brendl, the highly touted 19-year-old right wing from the Czech Republic, to join them for the A.H.L. semifinals.
The Rangers' season ended on April 9, without a playoff appearance for the third consecutive year. But the Rangers' top minor-league affiliate, Hartford, is still going strong.

On Sunday, Hartford wrapped up its A.H.L. quarterfinal series, 4 games to 1, with a 2-0 shutout of Worcester. And now, the Wolf Pack can expect Pavel Brendl, the highly touted 19-year-old right wing from the Czech Republic, to join them for the A.H.L. semifinals.

Brendl's junior-league career ended Saturday night with the Calgary Hitmen's 6-5 overtime loss to Kootenay in the Western Hockey League semifinals. Brendl, the Rangers' first pick in last summer's draft (fourth over all), contributed three assists in the Game 5 defeat, as Kootenay pulled off the upset, 4 games to 1. In 10 playoff games, Brendl has scored 7 goals and had 12 assists.
For Calgary this season, Brendl scored 59 goals in 61 games to lead the W.H.L. by 9 goals. In two junior-league seasons with Calgary, Brendl had 132 goals in 129 games.
Brendl had been penciled into the Rangers' opening-day lineup last fall. But he reported to his first National Hockey League training camp out of shape.
Brendl has agreed to report to the Rangers' practice facility in Rye, N.Y., on July 1 to work out with the training staff in preparation for training camp this fall.
